history.text: Not so sure about Harry Styles in this movie, just doesn't seem like a good fit to me.
Harry Styles surprised me with his ability to act, especially without a singing gimmick.
I think IMAX is the perfect format for telling a story of this magnitude.
Do you think the 70mm enhanced the storytelling?
I think it will be great to see a war movie from air, land and sea, too often it is just from one aspect.
I don't know if I think it did.
I think it helped convey the scale of the evacuation and added grandeur.
I can see that. Your right.
The massive set pieces were dazzling.
Did you like the pontoon set?
It was amazing how non manufactured everything appeared.
Yes it was amazing.
What did you think of Tommy and Gibson working together to help the wounded man?
They were great together, but horrible they couldn't be taken by the boat too.
I liked the element of humanity the scene added to the film.
Absolutely, it is nice to be able to connect like that to a piece.
Gibson, even though he is a French soldier, still helps them.
I know, it is nice to see there is always some good out there.
What do you think of the tension building through these scenes as the boys struggle to survive?
Oh watching the German troops use the boat as target practice, and us knowing they were inside, I couldn't imagine.
Especially as it fills with water!
What about when Gibson reveals he is French?
He has shown his humanity by helping others, so it was heartbreaking to see the others turn on him.
Seeing George's body carried away was a killer.
That was really hard to watch the officer they had saved inflict that trauma upon George.
It was incredible that they evacuated 300,000 soldiers. I thought the 70m really shined when seeing the scale of that.
Yes painful, but to know 300,000 were evacuated was amazing.
I agree with you there.  And how nice to see Dawson honored for saving so many men.
Yes, and to see the men honored when the train arrived at the station when they thought they would be scorned.
Did you like how much of the story was told with so little dialog?
Yes, and to see Tommy read the address.
Yes the minimal dialog was different but I think it worked for what they were trying to accomplish.
It takes incredible skill for a filmmaker to tell such a big, violent story with such delicacy.
Agreed, and Christopher Nolan nailed the directing.
The practical effects added to the production quality.
What did you think of Hoyte van Hoytema's cinematography?
They hit the nail on the head.
Which scenes do you think best utilized his talent?
The thousands of extras were impressive.
Yes, having so many extras in World War II period clothing and gear must have been a huge job for props and costumes.
The way they were able to recreate the period planes was amazing as well.
Yes, the production design was stunning. Those ships were quite impressive.
The whole thing was deeply moving
Did you have a favorite character?
I would say Dawson.
How about yourself?

I thought Gibson was very interesting, but of course I loved sweet 
George.
You can't help but love George.
I disagree with some of the critical response that said that it was "so concerned with its own spectacle and scale that it neglects to deliver the most crucial element- drama."
I thought the drama was handled with great finesse, and there was a delicate balancing act taking place between the spectacle of scale while simultaneously breathing life into characters.

Yes I agree with you there but I love that they gave Nolan credit, "There's little doubt that [Nolan] has, without sentimentality or sanctimony, raised that
genre to the level of art...with the resonant force of an enduring screen classic.", they were dead on with that.
I agree with that response.

uid2response.feedback: Dunkirk is an exquisite piece of modern filmmaking.
